Daily Universal Register

BRIEFING

Ireland: Leo Varadkar meets Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, in Dublin.

On this day

In 1581, on his return from circumnavigating the globe, Francis Drake was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I on board the Golden Hind; in 1687 King James II issued a declaration of indulgence permitting worship to take place outside the established Church of England; in 1818 the US Congress fixed the number of stripes in the American flag at 13, with one star to be added for each new state; in 1932 vitamin C was isolated by Charles Glen King, professor of chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh; in 1949, in Washington, 12 nations signed the North Atlantic Treaty for collective defence against the threat of Soviet aggression; in 1968 Martin Luther King Jr was assassinated while on a trip to support striking sanitation workers in Memphis, Tennessee.

Nature notes

We have five large, colourful butterflies that hibernate in the winter and come out in the spring. The yellow brimstone butterflies have been around for some weeks. They fly fast, sometimes sweeping across gardens without a pause to look around. The other four are all now emerging here and there in the sunshine. They settle more readily and give better views of themselves. Peacock butterflies, with the four rings, or eyes, on their velvety purple wings, often sit on a dry footpath. Small tortoiseshells, which are orange and black, flit round flowers before coming down. Comma butterflies, whose wings are like ragged tiger skins, often sit on fences. Red admirals, the largest and grandest of the four, only hibernate here in small numbers, mainly in the south, but summer visitors from the Continent will soon be streaming in.

Derwent May

Birthdays

Jonathan Agnew, BBC cricket correspondent (since 1991), 59; Delphine Arnault, executive vice-president, Louis Vuitton, 44; David Blaine, illusionist, 46; Johnny Borrell, guitarist and singer, Razorlight, Up All Night (2004), 39; Baroness (Karren) Brady, businesswoman, vice-chairwoman, West Ham United Football Club, adviser to Lord Sugar on The Apprentice (since 2009), 50; James Cuno, president and chief executive, J Paul Getty Trust, 68; Clive Davis, music producer, president, Columbia Records (1967-73), 87; Robert Downey Jr, actor, the Iron Man film series, 54; Jane Eaglen, soprano, 59; Trevor Griffiths, playwright, Comedians (1975), 84; Dave Hill, guitarist, Slade, Merry Xmas Everybody (1973), 73; Vladimir Jurowski, conductor, principal conductor and artistic adviser, London Philharmonic Orchestra, 47; Sheku Kanneh-Mason, cellist, BBC Young Musician of the Year award winner (2016), 20; Kitty Kelley, journalist and biographer, 77; Mary Kenny, journalist and author, Conversation before a Hanging (2016), 75; Sir Greg Knight, Conservative MP for East Yorkshire, industry minister (1996-97), 70; Cherie Lunghi, actress, Excalibur (1981), The Mission (1986), 67; Caroline Michel, chief executive, Peters Fraser & Dunlop literary agency, 60; Craig T Nelson, actor, Poltergeist (1982), 75; Monty Norman, composer, Dr No (1962), 91; Graham Norton, TV host, The Graham Norton Show, 56; Barry Reamsbottom, trade unionist and senior secretary to the Speaker of the House of Commons (2002-09), 70; Charles Sinclair, chairman, Associated British Foods (2008-18), 71; Derek Thompson, actor, Casualty (since 1986), 71; Dame Catherine Tizard, governor-general of New Zealand (1990-96), 88; Hugo Weaving, actor, The Hobbit film series (2012, 2014), 59; Admiral Sir George Zambellas, first sea lord and chief of the naval staff (2013-16), 61.

Daily Universal Register

BRIEFING

Ireland: Leo Varadkar meets Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, in Dublin.

On this day

In 1581, on his return from circumnavigating the globe, Francis Drake was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I on board the Golden Hind; in 1687 King James II issued a declaration of indulgence permitting worship to take place outside the established Church of England; in 1818 the US Congress fixed the number of stripes in the American flag at 13, with one star to be added for each new state; in 1932 vitamin C was isolated by Charles Glen King, professor of chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh; in 1949, in Washington, 12 nations signed the North Atlantic Treaty for collective defence against the threat of Soviet aggression; in 1968 Martin Luther King Jr was assassinated while on a trip to support striking sanitation workers in Memphis, Tennessee.

Nature notes

We have five large, colourful butterflies that hibernate in the winter and come out in the spring. The yellow brimstone butterflies have been around for some weeks. They fly fast, sometimes sweeping across gardens without a pause to look around. The other four are all now emerging here and there in the sunshine. They settle more readily and give better views of themselves. Peacock butterflies, with the four rings, or eyes, on their velvety purple wings, often sit on a dry footpath. Small tortoiseshells, which are orange and black, flit round flowers before coming down. Comma butterflies, whose wings are like ragged tiger skins, often sit on fences. Red admirals, the largest and grandest of the four, only hibernate here in small numbers, mainly in the south, but summer visitors from the Continent will soon be streaming in.

Derwent May
